label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, June 1, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, complimenting her description of a baseball game she attended, advising her on legal matters to do with the government attempts to seize parts of Medway Plantation, and speculating what their lives will be after the war. Sidney continues in his letter to praise how efficient she has become and describe his life on the island.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
No 1
Dear Gertie,
I received your letter of May 26th. and the enclosed copy of the
letter from George Buist this morning. As you do not speak of anyof letters
I am worried that they are not arriving. I am sorry as I am writing to you
every day and do not know what is happening to the mail. In order that
we may see just how bad it is I have numbered this letter 1 and from now
on will faithfully follow this method and you can let me know what is happening
as to the letters you receive.
Your discription of the ball game was heavenly. I thought the crooners,
and all the side shows were marvellous. It resembles a corner drug store.
Everything but drugs in the case of one[,] and everything but baseball in the case
of the other. That is how America seems to be. Without the sdie trim ings you
have nothing. Everything must be a double header or the crowds will not come.
Super salesmanship or nothing. When we have that little farm in Virginia
we will put you in charge of the sell ng and you will somehow convince people
that our carrots are the best in the world. I suppose our road side stand will
have a band and a few crooners going full tiltwhile hot water bottles and toasters
are sold on the side.
I am inclined to agree with George Buist that it is wiser to
accept an offer from the government in the amount of approximately $2O.00
and acre than take it to court because the law fees will eat up any bit
in excen that you might obtain. Further I do not think that the goverment will
take into consideration that we have lost a thing most valuable to us, the abilility
to ride over the countryside without interference feeling as free as the wind.
Neither will they consider that an amunition dump is not the happiest thing to
have next to our house. For these reasons I advise taking ard offer of twenty
dollars and at the same time going on written record with the government that
we paid fifty dollars an acre[,]as we paid one hundre[d]and ten thousand for the 2200
acres.
An entirely different situation arises when the claim for the land
taken for the canal is brought up in court. Here it will not be a question
of acrage but of distraction of bea[u]ty and the m[A]king of the place untenable as
a home. Besides the harm done the building by blasting etc. This will have to
go intothe courts unless they are willing to pay us plenty. If you approve of
the enclosed letter to George send it along after you have signed it. If you
do not approve rewrite it and than send it along telling him that I concurr
in your opinion.
Should you obtain approxmately six thougend dollars for the land
taken I would put int in a special account for thepurchase of another home somewehr[e]
after the war. We should be able to buy such a place purely with money obtained
from Medway land and timber and still hold the great part of Medway and the timber.
Do not put t[h]is money in your checking account or it will go like the wind.
[End Page 1]
I do not think we have to pay any income tax on any money received
for the sale of this land from the government because we paid fifty dollars an
acre and they are only giving us twenty so if anything it looks to me as if
we should be able to take a loss.
Nothing makes me laugh harder than when I read in your letters that you
sup ose I wil want to lead a bac[h]elor life after the war and you wonder how
I will react to our being together again. If there wasnt a censor I would tell
you exactly how I would react. In my mind there is not the slightest doubt
a[s] to our life together after his war. The only thing that is discourging
is that the end of the war seems so far off. However it will end some day
or they will retire me for old age. I t ink after sixty they will not let you
stay in the navy so then I will come home and we will do the t[h]ings we want to.
Men are really going back all the time, one that I knew just left, thought he
was going to be out here for a long time and he is off now. It is purely
a question of what the Bureau is feeling like as to where you go and what you
do. Probably if iPut in an application to remain in the Hawaiian islands the
reminder of my life I would be transferred to Iceland tomorrow. That is how
things work. You must not become discouraged with your job or our being
seperated. It will come to an end soon and then this year will seem very insig
nificant compared to the long years that will lie ahead of us.
The pestoring of the two air conditi[o]ning units to health and vigor was
marvellous. How wonderful and how like Washington to have two men work all
day in the home thinking they were doing work for someone else and then findin[g]
that they were in the wrong place after everthing had been finished. I am so
glad that you will have these units because they are the only way you can
ohtain any sleep.
The house in Watch Hill sounds marvellous and I am so glad you were
able to obtain one. You have become so efficent that I do not intend to do
one thing when I return. All check books , business papers and letters etc.
will be given to you while I lie in a hammock and sleep, read, pat honeys head
and grunt with pleasure ast se[e]ing everyone else work. Perhaps we had better
buy Rose a hoe now so she gets the habit of worldng in the fields hoeing de
cotton.
I have been swimming every day, but camot tell you anything about it
becaxuse after describing swimming and surf boarding several times there is
noting else to say about it. You repeat the same strokes, fall off the same way,
and think and see the same things. The water if anything is slightlxy bluer,
the waves much ,larger, [too large] and all the real old timers are now out
that[T]he surfing season has commenced. I never catch a wave anymore. They all
du[M]p me on my head, I also have not yet learned to do the crawl, this being
my twentieth year at trying to do it. I eat more than anyone else in Hawaii,
sleep wonderfuly , love the soft nights, palm trees and air heavy with perfume
and the tiny breezes that play amongst the palm fronds. I drink scotch, bourbon
rye, gin, champagne, and beer, ride about in my car, back and forth to work,
and would t[H]ink t is heaven on earth if only you were here. I miss you
terribly and send you all my love darling. You know everything bal[a]nces up
and now that to[D]ay is the anniversary of my arrival in Washington and Navy duti[e]s
perhaps the comming year will bring us together rather than apart. I certainly
hope and pray so.
P.S Will send you the letter
to George Buist tomorrow Sidney J Legendre
[End Page 2]
